case_title: Constitutionality of the Supreme Court (Practice and Procedure) Act, 2023
judges: Other 12 Judges of the Supreme Court
complaint_summary: Multiple petitions were filed under Article 184(3) of the Constitution challenging the Supreme Court (Practice and Procedure) Act, 2023, alleging it infringed judicial independence and exceeded Parliament's legislative competence.
investigation_summary: The petitions were reviewed by the Supreme Court to assess the constitutionality of the Act, focusing on its provisions regulating bench formation, suo motu powers, and appeal rights.
judgment_summary: The Supreme Court upheld the constitutionality of the Act by a majority of 10-5, except for Section 5(2), which was declared unconstitutional. The prospective right of appeal under Section 5(1) was upheld by a majority of 9-6, while the retrospective right of appeal under Section 5(2) was struck down by a majority of 8-7.
Decision_or_verdict: The Act was upheld except for Section 5(2), which was declared unconstitutional.
legal_arguments: Legislative competence under Article 191 and Federal Legislative List Entries 55 and 58.
Judicial independence and separation of powers.
Finality of judgments and retrospective application of appeal rights.
citations: Baz Muhammad Kakar v. Federation of Pakistan (PLD 2012 SC 923)
Iftikhar Muhammad Chaudhry v. President of Pakistan (PLD 2010 SC 61)
Al-Jehad Trust v. Federation of Pakistan (PLD 1996 SC 324)
key_issues: Legislative competence of Parliament under Article 191.
Impact of the Act on judicial independence.

maxims.Separation of Powers: The judiciary must remain independent from legislative and executive interference.

legal_terms.Ultra Vires: Beyond the powers of the legislative authority.
legal_terms.Suo Motu: Action taken by a court on its own initiative.

words_and_phrases.Judicial Independence: The principle that the judiciary operates free from external influences.
words_and_phrases.Finality of Judgments: The concept that judicial decisions, once made, should not be reopened.

summary_vector_notes: The Supreme Court of Pakistan reviewed the constitutionality of the Supreme Court (Practice and Procedure) Act, 2023, focusing on its provisions regulating bench formation, suo motu powers, and appeal rights. The Act was upheld except for Section 5(2), which was declared unconstitutional for violating principles of legal certainty and finality of judgments.
